choices: Hide by the shoes, and try to get noticed.
Go to the living room, and hide out under the coffee table.
Go to the kitchen, and hide by the baseboard underneath the cabinets.
Hide by the front door, and get ready to escape.
Before you get five steps, there's a thudding from the top of the stairs.
1.content:
You blink your eyes, as you try to adjust to the early morning light.

You yawn, briefly disoriented. You don't remember going to sleep. You remember going out for a walk -- just a short one, nothing crazy. You remember seeing that strange light that you went over to, and then it slid around you like a glove, and then --

-- then you woke up.

You sit up, heart racing and head pounding. You don't remember anything after that. And you're still wearing your shorts and shirt and shoes from the night before. And you're not in your bed.

It's that last one that really causes you to panic. You get up off the ground where you were laying. You aren't on the sidewalk near your house, either. You're laying on some vast plain made out of slightly rough wood. It's like a giant basketball court, only no baskets. You see some ways off a wall that seems to climb to infinity. Where are you -- some kind of warehouse?

No, it's bigger than that. In the dim light of the early morning, you see a building, the size of an office tower, draped in some sort of white fabric. You begin walking toward it, and that's when you see something that causes your heart to skip a beat.

It's some distance away, sitting near the base of the building. A white hill, sitting next to its twin. A white hill, with blue markings. Blue markings that are clearly and unmistakably a Nike swoosh.

By those hills sit some other monoliths, red that rise on stilts, smaller blue ones, larger black ones. All of them, a half-dozen pair in all, clearly shoes.

Shoes belonging to people who are so much bigger than you that your mind can't comprehend it.

You turn around, trying to get your bearings. You can see beyond the tower rises an enormous window, and beside it, a door. You're in an entryway. Where the people kick their shoes off at the end of the day. The tower is some sort of table.

Behind you, you see a set of stairs that climb to the heavens. Bedrooms are up there. You think you can spot a kitchen if you head left of the stairs and down the -- it seems impossible for this to be a hallway, but there you are. Another door seems to promise a living room.

You are in full panic, but you still know that you have to do something. You can't just stand in the middle of the hallway. You have to go get yourself secure someplace. And maybe get these people's attention. Or maybe try to avoid that at all costs.

You gather yourself. It's morning. They'll be getting up soon. You don't have a lot of time. The way you see it, you have a few options. If you want to get noticed, you could head over to the shoes. They'll stop by there on their way out. You can get their attention. Otherwise, you could go to the living room, and maybe get someone's attention there...somehow.

Then again, maybe you should head to to the kitchen. Whether you want to be found or not, there will be food there. And the family will probably go there in the morning. Or maybe you should try to escape the house altogether. If you just wait right by the door, you could slip out when they leave in the morning.

After thinking it over, you nod and head off for your destination. Once you secure yourself there, there's nothing to but wait for the giants who live here to awake.
1.title: Good Morning, Sleepyhead

choices: You were standing on it, and he sees you.
You were standing on it, but he doesn't see you.
You were standing on one of the other pairs of shoes, and he doesn't see you.
11.content:
Morning in the Stevenson household is like morning anywhere else. Jenna and Tim wake up earlier than they'd like; they briefly squabble over who has to go grab the paper (Jenna loses the argument this time. Tim probably will tomorrow), and then they go wake the kids. Emily's easy -- seven years old isn't too bad. The oldest two, however, are much tougher. Brianna is 14 and Jake is 16, and neither one wakes up before noon willingly.

Still, it's not that bad. At least their schedules are reasonably in sync. Tim leaves around 7:30 for the office, followed by Jenna at 8:15 -- she drops Emily on the way in to work. The teens are both in high school now, and Jake can drive, so they take off at 8:30 -- not that Jake likes driving his sister into school, but since he'd lose his car if he didn't, he puts up with it.

And so they gather 'round the breakfast table, with the older teens sullen and sleep-deprived, Emily her usual bundle of energy, and Tim and Jenna trying to impose order on the day.

"So, what's going on after school?" Jenna asks, pouring milk on Emily's cereal.

"I have soccer practice," Brianna yawns.

"Great. Do I have to wait around for her?" complains Jake.

"No, I can pick her up. What are you doing, though, that it's an issue?" asks Tim.

"He's got a date tonight," says Brianna.

"It's just a...thing," mutters Jake.

The conversation continues on for a moment, until Tim has to go to work; he walks over to the shoes, bends down, and slips his foot into the first half of his pair of dress shoes. He looks down at the second...
11.title: Getting Everyone Out the Door

111.content:
"Down Here! Help!"

You scream up to the man as you jump about the smooth leather surface of the shoe. He looks down upon you, at first for a split second but then he does a double take as your flailing arms just barely catch his attention.

"Damn bugs..." He mutters, too quiet for the rest of the family to hear.

Your heart sinks as his dress sock clad foot knocks you away from the shoe. With a simple step, the vast fabric-clad foot comes down upon you. It wasn't a brutal stomp but that didn't lessen the searing pain you felt as all your bones and body broke and burst under the immense weight and pressure of Tim's foot... Darkness.

---

Tim put his other shoe on and went to work. He didn't give another thought to the bug he had killed, unaware that it was a shrunken human. He only acted out of an instinct to protect his wife and youngest daughter, both he thought utterly terrified of bugs...
111.title: A Deadly Mistake

choices: You're standing on Jenna's red heels.

113.content:
You watched in amazement as the giant family paraded by you, each one shaking the floor in turn, even the little girl. Now, you watch in even more astonishment as the man of the house bends down and slides his shoes on.

You wave at him half-heartedly, but you know you won't be seen; you're on an entirely different pair of shoes. Why would he be looking at someone else's shoes? And if he did, why would he expect to see a bug-sized man?

He wouldn't. So as he straightens, you sigh, and look back down the hallway to the kitchen, where the rest of the giants remain. You look down at the shoe you're on, wondering if the next group to leave will see you.

1133.content:
"Bye Mom. I'm taking Twerp-anna to school," Jake calls from the doorway.

"Don't call me that, Jerkwad." The teenage girl angrily shoved her feet in her flats, storming away to the car before Jake could reply.

He watched after her. It was waaay too easy to set her off. He slipped his skate shoes on, not bothering with the laces. They were practically falling apart, anyways, with the sole peeling off and the fabric on the inside shredding freshly with every step. He'd been meaning to get new shoes for a while now, and with his date tonight... Maybe he'd stop at a shoe store on the way home from school.

Brianna was sitting in the passenger seat and looking out the window by the time he got there. "Ready to go, sis?"

"Don't talk to me."

Jake shook his head as the engine turned over. Women.

11331.content:
You fell from the top of the shoe into the sole, as the enormous girl slid the shoe back with her foot, never even looking down as she slid her foot into the light blue flat, while barking, "Don't call me that, jerkwad." She knocked you half a dozen feet into the shoe with her middle toe, and you had just enough sense to crawled and ran and struggled on further, until you found yourself in the very tip of the shoe, with her middle toe to your left and her second toe to your right. You clung to a stitch, trying not to slide back under the ball of her foot; it wasn't easy, as each step was like an earthquake as the girl stomped to the car. And there was no respite once she got in; she was tapping the foot impatiently, waiting for her brother.

Finally, she settles, and you feel the rumble of the car as it roars to life. Now, with a bit of rest, you have a chance to move a bit. You figure that you need to get on top of her foot, so you don't get squashed. Carefully, you move into the gap between her toes.

You're amazed that a young teen could have feet that smelled so bad. You suppose the scent, like everything else, is magnified. You find a bit of rough skin, and climb up until you're able to crawl out onto the webbing of her toes. You breathe heavily; that wasn't easy. And you've climbed up less than an inch.

The vibration of the car stops, and you brace yourself, hoping that you won't fall. The girl steps out of the car, and walks toward the school.
11331.title: Flat But Not Broke

"What do you think, Kira? When I have ever been ready?" Brianna sighed, leaning against the locker. "Can't you just take the test for me?"

Her friend just laughed. "That'd be cheating, Bree. Didn't you study?"

"No! Soccer practices drain me, so I've been just going home and sleeping. Uggh, why do we need algebra anyway."

Brrrrrrrrrrrrrrring!

"That's the bell." Kira moved in and gave Brianna a quick hug. "Best of luck!"

-----------------------------------------------------------

1) Subtract: (4g + 5) - (g + 2)

Shit. Didn't she have a rule about this? Distribution? Goddamn it, she was going to fail.

Well, this was going to be a looong period. Adjusting herself, she slipped her flats off and got comfortable in the seat.

1133122.content:
Once, back when you were normal sized, you had read that because of how blood vessels were arranged differently in men and women, women and especially young girls had colder hands and feet. You thought it an interesting tidbit, but figured that it'd never come in handy. Now, however, you could confirm it first hand. This teen's skin was absolutely frigid. Clinging to the whirls of her sole as she crossed her legs at the ankle, you felt like you'd spent the last half hour in a snowstorm. A very sweaty, smelly snowstorm.

You were only a foot's length above the ground but by god did it look much farther. You wanted off this terrible ride, but dropping from here could injure or even kill you, so you held on to the cold skin, shivering against it.

It could be worse. Above, you hear the rough sound of her toes grinding against each other. Skin-on-skin sounded a lot harsher from the size of an insect, and you had no desire to be in the midst of it. Gently, bits of lint drifted down from the action, floating by your handholds. It gave you an idea. If lint could float, could you? You reasoned that it would be possible, as some of the flecks that soared by were about your size.

Hell, it was worth a shot. You opened your hands, letting go...

...right as the foot swung upwards as the teen crossed her legs. You were sent flying off into the classroom at large.

Good news: Your theory was right. You were slowly descending, carried by air currents that kept your fall at a safe speed.

Bad news: Your landing zone seemed to be...
1133122.title: Mountain

Expand: 2X(X2+5X+3)

Brianna stared at the paper, trying to decipher to foreign symbols that she was supposed to be able to solve. Every problem was just... impossible. She erased the start of her answer, adding to the increasing amounts of pink rubber specks that dotted her work. Pressing hard onto the paper, she began to write out another attempt.

She had to pass this test. Her grade was sitting at a weak C. If it fell any further, she'd be off the soccer team, not to mention what her dad would say. Math just didn't come easily to her.

I must be the unluckiest person in the world.
11331221.title: Math Troubles

choices: Brianna uses her left hand to brush away eraser scraps
Brianna uses her left hand to brush some hair behind her ear
113312211.content:
Contact her directly, yessirree, that'll be easy...

You stand stock still for a full five minutes, just taking in the awesome landscape of the girl as she goes about a simple mathematics test. Bent over the desk and concentrating on the paper, she is still a mighty mountain range looming over you. She scribbles answers with a pencil dozens of storeys tall, held lightly in her thick fingers, but pressing down with enough force to gouge furrows in the paper, snapping large chunks of graphite in its wake. And when she makes an error, there's a furious rubbing with the eraser, fast and strong enough to obliterate a tank.

Intimidating doesn't begin to describe it.

When you've composed yourself, and checked that you haven't wet yourself, you begin walking slowly toward the massive girl. At least you don't have to worry about staying alert to dodge anything - if she decided to try and kill you, nothing you could do would stop her! That's... encouraging?

In her shadow, you step closer to her left hand, which lies still on the desk, a spread of great, fleshy barriers. While its mirrored twin scratches away, you reach out to grab the smallest finger, preparing yourself for clambering up the thick ridges of the skin.
113312211.title: It Seemed Like A Good Idea At The Time

choices: You are completely tangled in her hair.
You are holding on for life in her ear.
1133122112.content:
Bri puffed up her cheeks and sighed. Brushing a stray hair behind her ear, she took a moment to look around the class. She grimaced as she saw that nearly everyone else had long since finished and turned in their tests.

It's not my fault! she thought, her cheeks turning red. Math isn't fair! If this was English or chemistry or P.E., I'd be acing this stupid test. She glanced over her answers, her frown deepening as she realized just how many she had to guess on. This was going to tank her grade, yes siree, and Mom was gonna kill her.

The end of class bell pulled Brianna out of her slump. Turning in her sorry excuse for an answer sheet, she dragged her self slowly to her locker. She didn't really need anything special for the poetry class she had next period, but she hoped that Kira would be there to cheer her up. She wasn't, of course; her best friend had been busier and busier as the year went on, and that meant not a lot of time for hanging and chatting.

She brushed another hair out of her face (I'll see if I can borrow a hair scrunchy later), and trudged toward Mrs. Whit's class. She wasn't very strict, but with that F in math looming in her future she wasn't risking any other classes. Dropping into her seat a full minute before the bell, Brianna pulled out her class copy of The Poetry of Robert Frost and let her head fall to the desk.

Only five more periods and lunch in-between, and she could forget about this trash day and just kick some ass in on the soccer pitch.
1133122112.title: The day carries on

Brianna excuses herself to the restroom
11331221122.content:
Your heart nearly stops as you clutch onto a strand of this giant teen's hair, terrified of losing your grip and being flung into the unknown. The rope swings violently until the cavernous maw of her ear rapidly approaches, and when the strand of hair makes contact the impact causes you to lose grip and tumble into the darkness..!

Before you can even get your bearings everything lurches and sways, slamming you from wall to wall. Your head strikes the firm fleshy wall of her inner ear canal and you black out.

* * * *

Your eyes open, despite everything. With a groan you take a look at your surroundings. A black tunnel looms behind you, no doubt the entrance way into the labyrinth inside this teen's head. Going down there would probably be a bad idea. The exit leading out of ear is not too far away so fortunately it doesn't seem like you were thrown that deep. From your vantage point it's like a massive vestibule. You can even just see the outside world beyond it, the interior of a classroom so you don't seem to have been knocked out too long. You can even hear the teacher's droning voice coming from outside as she lectures on and on.

It's then that you realize you can't move. At first you worry you might have shattered your spine or something, but when you look down you find yourself plastered in a thick, waxy substance. Oh great.

You grunt and struggle, but you can't get the leverage to pull yourself out of the goop. Sweating, you despair at the idea of this being your fate. A girl you never met's earwax being your earthly tomb.

It's only then, while hearing the voice of the teacher reverberate all around you that you realize how stupid you're being. You're in an ear. If there was ever a better place someone of your stature would want to be, you couldn't think of it. Cupping your hands over your mouth, you scream into the darkness of the void behind you.

"HEY! HELP! I'M TINY AND STUCK IN YOUR EAR!!"

Almost immediately everything lurches violently causing you to shriek and fall backwards even deeper into the pile of wax. From outside you hear the teacher's voice.

"Is there a problem Miss Stevenson?"

"N-no. Sorry, I just thought I uh... never mind," your prisoner responded. No! You scream again.

"I'M HERE! I'M REAL AND TRAPPED! PLEAS--"

this time before you can even finish you scream as you see the girl's giant finger plow into the ear's entrance, darkening the light and causing the air pressure to pop. You scream and put your hands up as defense as the finger closes in on your position and everything goes dark.
11331221122.title: Waxwork

choices: You were shaken out of her ear
You're still in her ear
113312211222.content:
Brianna met her eyes in the bathroom mirror. She looked tired. Hell, she felt tired. First that algebra test ruined the morning, then she was reminded that her best friend was too busy for her, and to top it all off in just a couple hours was another game with this darn school's awful team...

Sighing, she splashed cold water over her face.

And now she was hearing... things? She refused to call the little squeaking in her ear a voice, no matter how much it resembled one, no matter how much it sounded like a small cry for help. She was fourteen, and way too young to be going crazy. Yet, if she focused her hearing, she could still catch it, faint and just on the edge of hearing, but there it was.

Gritting her teeth, Brianna shook here head. She shook it hard, will all the might she had. Her cheeks billowed and her hair flapped around her head like a stingy halo. She shook and shook and shook until her head was pounding and her eyes were tearing.

"Hmm." Shocked, Brianna turned to see an upperclassman walk out of a stall, frowning at the show. Bri blushed bright red, and rushed out of the restroom. It was worth it, though, as the little not-a-voice was gone.

Cherish the small victories, Bri. Cherish them, she thought, heading back to class.
113312211222.title: I'm not going crazy!

choices: The girl herself
The bathroom floor
1133122112221.content:
"AGGH!" You half gasp half scream as you go flying from the ear, hurdling through the air for just a moment before slamming into the a cold wall. You grimace, feeling the traces of wax that clung to you sticking you firmly to whatever surface you crashed on. Her ear was free of you but you weren't quite free of it.

You feel the air darken a bit. Trying to stay calm, you watch a different girl head in your direction, stopping a foot or so away to turn on the sink that resided far below. She began washing her hands; to her, a quick, routine act that was hardly worth a thought. To you, however, it was a display of force, more effective than any in history, as fingers that could crush city blocks lithely bent and slid over each other, throwing up frothy bubbles that could encapsulate small cars. Were you slipping, inching closer and closer to the grinding hands that scrubbed and scrubbed under Niagara Falls? Or was it just your imagination?

And then she was done. With a turn of the faucet and a quick shake of her hands, the show was over. But, before curtain fell and she made her exit, she stopped and looked at you.

Well, not at you. Above you. And behind you. She was looking at the wall you were stuck on. I'm on the bathroom mirror, you thought, trying to ignore the world's largest set of breasts that bounced in front of you. Her gaze was laser focused, picking out some tiny imperfection that even you couldn't spot. And, whatever issue she saw, she wasn't happy; her hand came up from the edge of the sink, still dripping from the wash, and began picking at something on her forehead.

Pick pick pick. With each twitch of muscle and tendon, she shed drops of water. They plummeted past you, each rivaling you in volume. You hoped she was done soon, but she was persistent. She leaned in closer, bringing her chest just inches away from you, and kept messing with her appearance. The drops kept falling, but this time they hit the mirror. One smashed down just below you, and another right to your side, leaving shining trails as they slid down the glass.

And then one hit, dead on, soaking you to your bones. You let out a scream-turned-gurgle as the waxy bonds broke, sending you hurdling off the mirror like a soping wet, super small comet. The sink's drain, an all consuming void that had just finished swallowing the thousands of gallons of soap and water this girl had used, opened up beneath you. You're helpless, screaming your way down to a watery death when from the side swipes in a living wall of skin; the girl's hand. You're flung to the side, the world a blur of water and pain and g-forces, as the backhand sends you tumbling towards...

Come on. Having made no progress, she brought up her other hand. She didn't notice as she batted a plummeting mite back in her direction. It landed...

113312212.content:
Bracing your shoulder, you shoved against the massive pink rubber chunk. It was one of many, torn off in a flurry of action when the giant girl began to erase a mistake. These mutilated chunks were certainly bigger than you, but they were all that you could reasonably interact with.

Your original plan was to form a message out of them, a simple "help" or "SOS." That proved to be beyond your ability, so you've instead settled with pushing them all in a line. Less specific, sure, but it should still grab the giant's attention. Hopefully soon, as you wouldn't want to be on here when she turns her test in.

It seems like your plan is working. She peers over, her blue billboard-sized eyes focusing down on you. "Hey! Down here!" you shout, hoping beyond hope she'll hear. She leans in closer, her face taking up your field of vision. You'd not had the chance to see it so close yet, considering your whole morning was spent on the floor and in a shoe. It was an unnerving experience, with her mouth big enough to chew through mountains and her nostrils wide enough to drive through.

"On the paper! Please, notice me!" You watch her lips, massive fleshy walls, contort and twist, hopeful until the girl...
113312212.title: Emergency Testing

choices: She crushed you to death
She flicked you away
1133122121.content:
Great, just great. On top of an impossible math test, troubles with boys, an asshole older brother, and a difficult soccer season, she had to deal with bugs in the school? Didn't they have janitors here or something? She leaned back in her chair, grimacing at the little dot scamper across the paper, probably leaving a trail of deadly germs and poo. Absolutely disgusting.

She raised her thumb over it. It'd be easy to crush it, just to end its life right here and now. Heck, the poor little thing was smaller than the eraser shavings it was running between. She could just lower the finger, let the pad of her thumb roll over it, her soft skin turning into a deadly, crushing wall. But, then she'd have to touch it. It'd get its nasty germs all over her skin, and she couldn't get up to wash her hands in the middle of a test.

What else was around? She could grab her shoe, but that'd get her yelled at for sure. Her pencil? No, she had to write with that still, and she wasn't going to filth it up with the bug. There was no way around it; if she was going to smush it, it'd have to be with her own hand.

A thought struck her. Did she really have to kill it? It wasn't her fault it was here in the school, after all. If she just got rid of it, her problems would be solved. But what if she did that, if she let the bug escape with its life. Would it just go into some dank corner and lay a clutch of horrifying bug eggs? Then there'd be more of them, and she didn't want to deal with that, either.

Holding her breath, she acted quickly. It was over just as it started. She was glad for that little distraction, but with a moan of resignation, she returned to her math test.
1133122121.title: Out of your hands

3 or 4
